factoid: Pierre looked around with his shortsighted eyes.
Pierre did not obey the surrounding people.
Pierre experienced doubts in his mind.
Pierre asked himself, "Where am I?"
Pierre asked himself, "What am I doing?"
Pierre asked himself, "Aren’t they laughing at me?"
Pierre asked himself, "Shan’t I be ashamed to remember this?"
The doubts that Pierre had lasted only a moment.
Pierre glanced at the serious faces of the people around him.
Pierre remembered all that he had already gone through.
Pierre realized that he could not stop halfway.
Pierre was aghast at his hesitation.
Pierre tried to arouse his former devotional feeling.
Pierre prostrated himself before the Gates of the Temple.
Pierre’s feeling of devotion returned to him even more strongly than before.
Pierre had lain there for some time.
Pierre was told to get up.
A white leather apron was put on Pierre.
Pierre was given a trowel.
Pierre was given three pairs of gloves.
The Grand Master addressed Pierre.
The Grand Master told Pierre that he should do nothing to stain the whiteness of the apron.
The apron symbolized strength and purity.
The Grand Master told Pierre to toil with the trowel to cleanse his own heart from vice.
The Grand Master told Pierre to use the trowel to smooth his neighbor’s heart.
The Grand Master said that Pierre could not know the meaning of the first pair of gloves but must keep them.
The Grand Master said that Pierre should wear the second pair of gloves at meetings.
The Grand Master said that the third pair of gloves were women’s gloves.
The Grand Master said that Pierre should give the third pair of gloves to the woman whom he shall honor most of all.
The Grand Master said that the gift would be a pledge of Pierre’s purity of heart to the woman he selects to be his worthy helpmeet in Masonry.
The Grand Master said that Pierre should beware that these gloves do not deck hands that are unclean.
Pierre grew embarrassed.
Pierre grew confused.
Pierre blushed like a child until tears came to his eyes.
Pierre looked about him uneasily.
An awkward pause followed.
One of the brethren broke the silence.
The brethren led Pierre up to the rug.
The brethren began reading to Pierre from a manuscript book an explanation of all the figures on it.
The figures on the manuscript included the sun, the moon, a hammer, a plumb line, a trowel, a rough stone, a squared stone, a pillar, and three windows.
A place was assigned to Pierre.
Pierre was shown the signs of the Lodge.
Pierre was told the password.
Pierre was permitted to sit down.
The Grand Master began reading the statutes.
The statutes were very long.
Pierre was not in a state to understand what was being read.
Pierre managed to follow only the last words of the statutes.
The last words of the statutes remained in Pierre’s mind.
The Grand Master read, "In our temples we recognize no other distinctions, but those between virtue and vice."
The Grand Master read, "Beware of making any distinctions which may infringe equality."
The Grand Master read, "Fly to a brother’s aid who ever he may be."
The Grand Master read, "Exhort him who goeth astray."
The Grand Master read, "Raise him that falleth."
The Grand Master read, "Never bear malice or enmity toward thy brother."
The Grand Master read, "Be kindly and courteous."
The Grand Master read, "Kindle in all hearts the flame of virtue."
The Grand Master read, "Share thy happiness with thy neighbor."
The Grand Master read, "May envy never dim the purity of that bliss."
The Grand Master read, "Forgive thy enemy, do not avenge thyself except by doing him good."
The Grand Master read, "Thus fulfilling the highest law thou shalt regain traces of the ancient dignity which thou hast lost."
The Grand Master finished.
The Grand Master embraced Pierre.
The Grand Master kissed Pierre.
Pierre had tears of joy in his eyes.
Pierre looked round him.
Pierre did not know how to answer the congratulations and greetings from acquaintances that met him on all sides.
Pierre acknowledged no acquaintances but saw in all these men only brothers.
Pierre burned with impatience to set to work with them.
The Grand Master rapped with his mallet.
All the Masons sat down in their places.
One of the Masons read an exhortation on the necessity of humility.
The Grand Master proposed that the last duty should be performed.
The distinguished dignitary who bore the title of Collector of Alms went round to all the brothers.
Pierre would have liked to subscribe all he had, but fearing that it might look like pride, subscribed the same amount as the others.
The meeting was at an end.
On reaching home Pierre felt as if he had returned from a long journey on which he had spent dozens of years.
Pierre had become completely changed.
Pierre had left behind his former habits and way of life.
